head.supplied: Dictated ¶ Melbourne 5-3-96 ¶ ¶ Let me acknowledge dear Professor Setchell the receipt of your kind letter dated 3th February, ¶ and let me assure you that I shall always be glad to hear from you. I...

div.p: University Herbarium, University of California, Berkeley.

Dictated
MS written by a clerk and signed by M, evidently without correcting misspellings.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
Let me acknowledge dear Professor Setchell the receipt of your kind letter dated 3th February,
Letter not found. and let me assure you that I shall always be glad to hear from you. It will afford me pleasure to send you some Australian Fucaceae but they do not occur near Melbourne, but mainly at the open Ocean outside this large bay.
Port Phillip Bay. In my museum I have only typical specimens, no duplicates, as the latter are always quickly consumed in interchanges. I will send you also miscellenious algs crudly dried, which can be resoaked and prepared in Callefornia and you will easely be able to make out at least the genera to which they belong. I am much beholden to you to send me your excellent Treaticess on American Algs.
None of the works by Setchell on algae listed in the catalogue of the library at MEL were published before 1896; M may have been referring to articles in the series under the title 'Contributions from the Cryptogamic Laboratory of Harvard University', published in Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences (for example Setchell (1890)) or in other journals (for example Setchell (1893)). It is hardly necessary to say that I shall be glad to add as gems Callifornian Algs named by you to the large collection of dried plants which I commenced in 1839 and which embraces now about one million sheets. A very large portion of this were my private property, but I located also that as a permanent gift in the museum here established by myself since 1853. — Your wish to posess a portrait of mine for Your Herbariam Hall I accede to with pleasure feeling quite proud with the request.
A copy of the portrait (P(1892)67a) still exists in the University Herbarium at Berkeley and is inscribed by M: 'To Prof. Will. Alb. Setchell for friendly remembrance from Ferd. von Mueller 1896'. — You will have lamented the death of Professor Eaton, whose biography you so touchingly give.
Setchell (1895). Perhaps you are not aware that he to some extent was drawn into his Algologic path by myself in as much as I sent more than thirty years ago a large lot of crisply dried Algs to Professor Asar Gray in interchange who handed the parcel over to Prof. Eaton and this gave to the latter a new or additional imputus for studying oceanic vegetation. With regrett I must tell you and Mis Eastwood that a package or case of Californian from your Herbarium destined for me some months ago did never arrive here, it came safely to Sydney, but as the American mailsteamer terminates there the consignment was lost in transmission and all endeavours to trace it have been in vain. I am very sorry indeed for this loss.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: P.S. The simplest quickest and cheapest methodes for our interchanges would be to send dried plants in ½ lb parcels by ordinary post, several of these could be sent by one mail. — I am not quite well.

As I have hardly any duplicates of Eucalypts and Acacias, I would suggest to send me of your dubious species leaves flowers and seedvessels ( ripe ) also notes on bark of advanced trees, I will then be happy to give the names. The same plan is adopted in South Africa.
As I have … Africa written by M.
